intro: Gaylussacia pseudovaccinium var. pubescens, commonly known as the pubescent cranberry shrub, is a species of evergreen shrub native to the southeastern United States. It is characterized by its dense, low-growing habit and clusters of small, red berries that ripen in the fall. The leaves are typically elliptical, with a leathery texture and a pubescent surface covered in fine hairs. This plant thrives in acidic, sandy soils and is often found in coastal dunes and wetlands. Its botanical features make it an important component of the local ecosystem, supporting various wildlife species.
